bibl.title: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, December 21, 1951

div1.p: Rath informs Hench that his attempt to preserve Building No. 1 lies outside the purview of the National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings because of the Cuban government's involvement. He suggests raising funds through a medical fraternity, possibly with the sanction of the American Medical Association or the Walter Reed Memorial Association.

Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
A brief vacation, a broken rib, and an out-of-town business
trip have served to pile up enough work so that I could not give full
attention to our correspondence about Building No. 1 at Quemados, Cuba.
Yesterday, however, General U. S. Grant, 3rd, President of the National
Council for Historic Sites and Buildings, and I did get to discussing
the problem confronting you.

As I told you, the cause you have fought for so vigorously
has ramifications outside our experience, largely because of the smoke-
screen built up by the Cuban government. Analysis would only seem to
yield the conclusion that it is the present regime that must be moved
to action - either with or without matching American donations. Even
though you state that matching donations will be necessary, I note that
in 1948 they refused any material help from you. Is it not possible
that it would be a matter of pride to do the job themselves, if they
could be impelled to act?

Before I deal with the matter of impelling them to act, let
me ask whether the medical fraternity could not be enlisted to support
a fund for the purpose, should it prove necessary? Possibly with the
sanction of the American Medical Association, a special foundation,
qualifying for tax exemption under Section 101 (6) of the Internal
Revenue Code, could collect tax-free contributions from American doctors.
It is simply an idea I thought worth mentioning, not because I believed
you had not thought of it but because we do know how to tell you to go
about setting such a foundation. I recognize that there is a Walter
Reed Memorial Association. It may be that it is the only instrument
you need to embark on such a campaign, if it properly activated, gets
official or unofficial sanction for the project, and then solicit the
right sources.

About impelling action - you have gone far along those lines
already. Perhaps in January you can go further. It may not be signi-
ficant, but I think we could arm you with a letter from General Grant
supporting the project. As President of the National Council for His-
toric Sites and Buildings, he represents a hundred organizations con-
cerned with preservation of the American heritage. It is no stretch
of the imagination, as we know, to include the yellow-fever battle and
Dr. Walter Reed's part in it as part of the American heritage. We
could urge the present Cuban government to complete the national monu-
ment in a manner befitting the great country of Cuba - that sort of
thing. Perhaps the present Surgeon-General might be able to do the
same.

I note that you are going to Cuba in January. Would it be
feasible at that time for you to come through Washington, if you are
embarking from the East Coast? Barring conflict of schedules, I be-
lieve that General Grant would be delighted to join us at lunch and a
discussion of this matter. We should like to help in some manner,
even if we are in no position to contribute financially to individual
projects.
